questions.stem: A client with blood-injection-injury (BII) phobia is referred for treatment. The therapist plans to use exposure therapy. Which additional technique is specifically indicated for this phobia subtype, and why?

options.text: Progressive muscle relaxation to reduce overall physiological arousal before exposure
Applied tension to counteract the vasovagal response and prevent syncope during exposure
Diaphragmatic breathing to prevent hyperventilation during blood-related exposures
Cognitive restructuring targeting catastrophic beliefs about fainting before introducing exposure

questions.explanation: BII phobia is unique among phobias because it involves a diphasic physiological response: initial sympathetic activation followed by a strong parasympathetic response (vasovagal syncope). Applied tension (Ost & Sterner) involves tensing the large muscles of the body during exposure to maintain blood pressure and prevent fainting. Relaxation training is actually contraindicated for BII phobia because it would further lower blood pressure.

questions.stem: According to the inhibitory learning model (Craske et al., 2014), what is the primary mechanism by which exposure therapy reduces fear?

options.text: Erasure of the original fear memory through repeated non-reinforced CS presentations
Formation of a new, competing inhibitory association (CS-no US) that suppresses the original fear memory
Habituation of the sympathetic nervous system through prolonged and repeated physiological arousal
Reciprocal inhibition of the anxiety response through pairing the feared stimulus with a relaxation state

questions.explanation: The inhibitory learning model proposes that exposure does not erase the original fear memory but rather creates a new, competing inhibitory association (CS-no US). This new association competes with the original fear memory for retrieval. This model has largely replaced the habituation model as the prevailing theoretical account. Strategies to enhance inhibitory learning include expectancy violation, deepened extinction, variability, and occasional reinforced extinction.

questions.stem: A clinician is treating a client with PTSD who reports overwhelming guilt and self-blame related to a sexual assault, stating 'It was my fault because I should not have been walking alone.' Which PTSD treatment would be MOST appropriate to target these cognitions directly?

options.text: Prolonged Exposure (PE), as imaginal exposure will directly extinguish the guilt response
EMDR, as bilateral stimulation will reprocess the maladaptive guilt cognitions
Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), as it specifically targets maladaptive 'stuck points' including self-blame
Trauma-Focused CBT (TF-CBT), as the PRACTICE components address guilt through cognitive coping

questions.explanation: CPT (Resick) specifically targets maladaptive trauma-related cognitions called 'stuck points.' The client's self-blame statement is an example of an assimilated stuck point, where the trauma is distorted to fit pre-existing beliefs. CPT uses Socratic questioning and cognitive worksheets to help modify these distorted beliefs across five themes: safety, trust, power/control, esteem, and intimacy. While PE is also first-line for PTSD, it emphasizes exposure to the trauma memory rather than direct cognitive restructuring. TF-CBT is designed for children and adolescents ages 3-18.

questions.stem: Which of the following BEST describes the difference between systematic desensitization and flooding?

options.text: Systematic desensitization uses imaginal exposure while flooding uses in vivo exposure exclusively
Systematic desensitization uses graduated exposure paired with relaxation, while flooding involves prolonged exposure to the most feared stimulus without relaxation
Systematic desensitization is based on operant conditioning while flooding is based on classical conditioning
Systematic desensitization requires medication augmentation while flooding relies solely on behavioral techniques

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization (Wolpe, 1958) pairs graduated exposure with relaxation training, based on reciprocal inhibition -- the idea that anxiety and relaxation are mutually incompatible states. The client progresses through a fear hierarchy using SUDS ratings. Flooding involves prolonged exposure to the most anxiety-provoking stimulus without a graduated hierarchy and without relaxation training, relying instead on habituation through extended contact. Both can use imaginal or in vivo formats.

questions.stem: A therapist treating a client with panic disorder conducts an exercise in which the client hyperventilates for 30 seconds, then rates the similarity of the induced sensations to their natural panic symptoms. This technique is BEST described as:

options.text: In vivo exposure to feared situations associated with panic attacks
Interoceptive exposure designed to reduce fear of bodily sensations through habituation
Systematic desensitization using progressive muscle relaxation before sensation provocation
Imaginal exposure to the worst-case scenario of having a panic attack in public

questions.explanation: Interoceptive exposure involves deliberately provoking feared bodily sensations to reduce fear of those sensations. In CBT for panic disorder (Clark, Barlow & Craske), common interoceptive exercises include hyperventilation (dizziness, tingling), breathing through a straw (air hunger), spinning (dizziness), and running in place (elevated heart rate). The client rates the similarity of each exercise to their natural panic symptoms and begins with exercises most closely matching their feared sensations.

questions.stem: Select ALL strategies that the inhibitory learning model (Craske et al., 2014) recommends to enhance exposure therapy outcomes:

options.text: Maximizing expectancy violation by creating a mismatch between predicted and actual outcomes
Ensuring habituation occurs within each session before ending the exposure trial
Varying exposure parameters (context, duration, intensity) across sessions
Using deepened extinction by combining multiple fear cues during a single exposure trial
Always progressing through the fear hierarchy in a strict low-to-high order

questions.explanation: The inhibitory learning model recommends several strategies to enhance new learning during exposure: (1) expectancy violation -- maximizing the mismatch between expected and actual outcomes; (2) variability -- varying exposure parameters across sessions to prevent context-dependent learning; (3) deepened extinction -- combining multiple fear cues during exposure; (4) occasional reinforced extinction; (5) affect labeling; and (6) retrieval cues. Within-session habituation is NOT required by this model, and strict hierarchical progression is not emphasized -- the focus is on maximizing new inhibitory learning.

questions.stem: Select ALL components that are part of Foa's Prolonged Exposure (PE) protocol for PTSD:

options.text: Psychoeducation about common trauma reactions
Imaginal exposure through repeated detailed revisiting of the traumatic memory
Written trauma account using ABC worksheets and Challenging Beliefs Worksheets
In vivo exposure to avoided but objectively safe trauma-related situations
Breathing retraining as a coping skill

questions.explanation: PE consists of four components: (1) psychoeducation about trauma reactions, (2) breathing retraining, (3) imaginal exposure -- repeated detailed revisiting of the traumatic memory in session, narrated in present tense with eyes closed, usually 45-60 minutes, recorded for homework listening, and (4) in vivo exposure to avoided but objectively safe trauma-related situations. ABC worksheets and Challenging Beliefs Worksheets are components of CPT (Resick), not PE.

questions.stem: A client presents with contamination-focused OCD. Select ALL accurate statements about Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) for this client:

options.text: ERP involves both exposure to obsession-triggering stimuli and refraining from compulsive rituals
Response prevention targets behavioral compulsions but NOT mental rituals such as counting or praying
ERP works by breaking the negative reinforcement cycle in which compulsions reduce obsessional distress
ERP produces response rates of 60-80% with significant symptom reduction
SSRIs are generally more effective than ERP alone for long-term OCD outcomes

questions.explanation: ERP involves two components: exposure to obsession-triggering stimuli and response prevention (refraining from compulsive rituals). Response prevention targets BOTH behavioral compulsions AND mental rituals (counting, praying, mental reviewing). ERP works by breaking the negative reinforcement cycle. Response rates are 60-80%. Research shows ERP alone produces equivalent or superior long-term outcomes compared to medication alone, with lower relapse rates after discontinuation.

questions.stem: Select ALL accurate statements about the EMDR 8-phase protocol:

options.text: Phase 3 (Assessment) involves activating the target memory and identifying the negative cognition, positive cognition, VOC, SUDS, and body location
Phase 4 (Desensitization) continues bilateral stimulation until SUDS reaches 0
Phase 5 (Installation) strengthens the positive cognition until VOC reaches 7
Phase 6 (Body Scan) identifies residual somatic disturbance for further processing
Component analyses have conclusively demonstrated that bilateral stimulation is the essential active ingredient in EMDR

questions.explanation: All descriptions of phases 3-6 are accurate. However, the mechanism debate around EMDR continues. Component analyses have yielded mixed results, and some researchers argue that the exposure and cognitive restructuring elements, rather than bilateral stimulation, account for EMDR's efficacy. The bilateral stimulation component has NOT been conclusively shown to be the essential active ingredient.

questions.stem: Select ALL components included in the TF-CBT PRACTICE acronym for treating childhood PTSD:

options.text: Psychoeducation and Parenting skills
Relaxation and Affective modulation
Cognitive coping and processing
Trauma narrative and In vivo mastery
Pharmacological management and Individualized behavior plans

questions.explanation: TF-CBT (Cohen, Mannarino, & Deblinger) uses the PRACTICE acronym: Psychoeducation, Parenting skills, Relaxation, Affective modulation, Cognitive coping and processing, Trauma narrative, In vivo mastery, Conjoint sessions (sharing the narrative with the caregiver), and Enhancing safety. Pharmacological management and individualized behavior plans are not part of this mnemonic. TF-CBT is for children and adolescents ages 3-18 and includes parallel child and caregiver sessions.

questions.stem: Match each anxiety/trauma treatment to the developer most associated with it:
questions.explanation: Prolonged Exposure was developed by Edna Foa based on emotional processing theory. CPT was developed by Patricia Resick targeting trauma-related stuck points. Systematic desensitization was developed by Joseph Wolpe based on the principle of reciprocal inhibition. EMDR was developed by Francine Shapiro based on the Adaptive Information Processing model.

questions.stem: Match each type of exposure to its MOST typical clinical application:
questions.explanation: Interoceptive exposure deliberately provokes feared bodily sensations and is a key component of CBT for panic disorder. Imaginal exposure involves detailed visualization and is used for processing trauma memories in PTSD (PE). In vivo exposure is direct real-life confrontation and is the standard for specific phobias, social anxiety, and agoraphobia. VR exposure uses computer-simulated environments and is particularly useful for phobias where in vivo exposure is impractical (flying, heights) or combat-related PTSD.

questions.stem: Select ALL medication classes that are considered appropriate for each anxiety disorder. Multiple selections per row are expected:
questions.explanation: GAD can be treated with SSRIs (first-line), benzodiazepines (short-term), and buspirone (chronic GAD, no sedation/dependence). Panic disorder is treated with SSRIs (first-line) and benzodiazepines (acute/short-term); buspirone is NOT effective for panic. Performance anxiety is specifically treated with beta-blockers (propranolol) which block peripheral sympathetic symptoms. OCD is treated with SSRIs (often at higher doses than for depression); benzodiazepines, buspirone, and beta-blockers are not standard OCD treatments.

questions.stem: Select ALL characteristics that correctly describe each PTSD treatment approach. Multiple selections per row are possible:

columns.text: Uses Socratic questioning and cognitive worksheets
Includes imaginal exposure to the trauma memory

questions.explanation: PE involves imaginal exposure (repeated narration of the trauma memory). CPT uses Socratic questioning and cognitive worksheets (ABC and Challenging Beliefs Worksheets) to modify stuck points. EMDR uses bilateral stimulation AND involves focusing on the trauma memory during desensitization (a form of imaginal exposure). TF-CBT includes a caregiver component (parallel sessions, conjoint sessions) and a trauma narrative component (graduated imaginal exposure).

questions.stem: In ACT, the six core processes depicted in the {{blank1}} model promote {{blank2}}, which is the central therapeutic target. Unlike traditional CBT, ACT explicitly rejects {{blank3}} as a treatment goal, instead focusing on helping clients engage in {{blank4}}.

options.text: hexaflex
biopsychosocial
transtheoretical
cognitive triad
psychological flexibility
cognitive restructuring
symptom habituation
reciprocal inhibition
symptom reduction
behavioral activation
cognitive defusion
interpersonal effectiveness
values-driven behavior even in the presence of difficult internal experiences
graduated exposure to increasingly feared stimuli
cognitive restructuring of irrational beliefs
relaxation responses to counter anxious arousal

questions.explanation: ACT (Hayes, Strosahl, & Wilson) uses the hexaflex model depicting six core processes: acceptance, cognitive defusion, being present, self-as-context, values clarification, and committed action. These promote psychological flexibility -- the ability to contact the present moment and engage in values-driven behavior even in the presence of difficult internal experiences. ACT explicitly rejects symptom reduction as a treatment goal, which distinguishes it from traditional CBT.

questions.stem: CPT identifies maladaptive trauma-related cognitions called {{blank1}}. When a client distorts the trauma to fit pre-existing beliefs (e.g., 'It was my fault'), this is called an {{blank2}} stuck point. When pre-existing beliefs are distorted to fit the trauma (e.g., 'No one can be trusted'), this is called an {{blank3}} stuck point. CPT addresses these across five themes: safety, trust, power/control, {{blank4}}.

options.text: stuck points
automatic thoughts
core beliefs
cognitive distortions
assimilated
over-accommodated
externalized
internalized
over-accommodated
assimilated
generalized
consolidated
esteem, and intimacy
identity, and attachment
autonomy, and competence
meaning, and connection

questions.explanation: CPT (Resick) targets 'stuck points' -- maladaptive trauma-related cognitions. Assimilated stuck points involve distorting the trauma to fit pre-existing beliefs (e.g., self-blame). Over-accommodated stuck points involve distorting pre-existing beliefs to fit the trauma (e.g., global distrust). The five themes are safety, trust, power/control, esteem, and intimacy.

questions.stem: A client with panic disorder avoids exercise, driving on the highway, and crowded places due to fear that physical sensations will trigger a heart attack. The client's heart rate elevation during mild exertion triggers intense anxiety and escape behavior.

options.text: Catastrophic misinterpretation of bodily sensations (e.g., 'racing heart = heart attack')
Avoidance of situations that produce feared physical sensations
Biological vulnerability to low serotonin levels causing spontaneous panic
Early childhood attachment disruption leading to separation anxiety
Clark's cognitive model of panic disorder (fear of fear cycle)
Foa's emotional processing theory of PTSD
Borkovec's worry-as-cognitive-avoidance model of GAD
Interoceptive exposure to deliberately induce and habituate to feared bodily sensations
Cognitive restructuring of catastrophic misinterpretations of somatic symptoms
Imaginal flooding with psychodynamic content about unconscious death anxiety
Applied tension exercises to prevent vasovagal syncope during exposure

questions.explanation: This presentation exemplifies Clark's cognitive model of panic disorder: normal bodily sensations are catastrophically misinterpreted, producing anxiety that intensifies sensations in a vicious cycle. The contributing factors are catastrophic misinterpretation and avoidance behavior. Treatment involves interoceptive exposure (deliberately inducing feared sensations) and cognitive restructuring of catastrophic beliefs. Applied tension is for BII phobia, and imaginal flooding with psychodynamic content describes implosive therapy (Stampfl).

questions.stem: A combat veteran with PTSD reports intense nightmares, hypervigilance, emotional numbing, and avoidance of any reminders of deployment. He states he cannot discuss what happened and immediately changes the topic when his trauma is mentioned.

options.text: Avoidance of trauma-related cues prevents emotional processing of the fear structure
The pathological fear structure is activated by trauma cues but maintained by avoidance
Cognitive fusion with trauma-related verbal rules creates experiential avoidance
Over-accommodation of beliefs about safety produces global distrust
Foa's emotional processing theory
Shapiro's Adaptive Information Processing model
Craske's inhibitory learning model
Imaginal exposure: repeated narration of the trauma memory in present tense until distress decreases
In vivo exposure to avoided but objectively safe trauma-related situations
Bilateral stimulation through saccadic eye movements while focusing on the target memory
Challenging Beliefs Worksheets to modify assimilated and over-accommodated stuck points

questions.explanation: This avoidance-dominant PTSD presentation aligns with Foa's emotional processing theory, which proposes that PTSD involves a pathological fear structure maintained by avoidance. The fear structure contains stimulus, response, and meaning representations. Successful processing requires activation of the entire fear structure followed by integration of corrective information. PE treatment involves imaginal exposure (narrating the trauma in present tense, 45-60 minutes, recorded for homework) and in vivo exposure to safe avoided situations. Bilateral stimulation is EMDR, and Challenging Beliefs Worksheets are CPT components.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are clinically accurate regarding the use of benzodiazepines with exposure therapy for anxiety disorders.
questions.passage: Research on combining benzodiazepines with exposure therapy has produced important findings for clinical practice. [Concurrent benzodiazepine use during exposure therapy is generally discouraged because it may interfere with extinction learning]. Some clinicians argue that [benzodiazepines enhance exposure therapy by reducing initial anxiety to a manageable level, allowing the client to engage more fully with feared stimuli]. The concern is based partly on [state-dependent learning theory, which suggests that fear extinction learned in a benzodiazepine-modulated state may not transfer to the drug-free state]. Research suggests that [D-cycloserine, an NMDA receptor partial agonist, may enhance extinction learning when administered before exposure sessions]. Additionally, [benzodiazepines are recommended as first-line augmentation for all clients who have difficulty tolerating initial exposure sessions]. Evidence also indicates that [safety behaviors, including reliance on anxiolytic medication, can prevent disconfirmation of feared consequences during exposure].

highlightableSegments.text: Concurrent benzodiazepine use during exposure therapy is generally discouraged because it may interfere with extinction learning
benzodiazepines enhance exposure therapy by reducing initial anxiety to a manageable level, allowing the client to engage more fully with feared stimuli
state-dependent learning theory, which suggests that fear extinction learned in a benzodiazepine-modulated state may not transfer to the drug-free state
D-cycloserine, an NMDA receptor partial agonist, may enhance extinction learning when administered before exposure sessions
benzodiazepines are recommended as first-line augmentation for all clients who have difficulty tolerating initial exposure sessions
safety behaviors, including reliance on anxiolytic medication, can prevent disconfirmation of feared consequences during exposure

questions.explanation: Concurrent benzodiazepine use during exposure therapy is generally discouraged due to state-dependent learning concerns -- extinction learned under medication may not generalize to drug-free states. D-cycloserine (NMDA partial agonist) may enhance extinction learning when given before sessions (though results are mixed). Safety behaviors, including medication reliance, can prevent disconfirmation of feared consequences. Benzodiazepines are NOT recommended as first-line augmentation for all exposure clients, and the claim that they 'enhance' exposure by reducing anxiety is contrary to research evidence.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL accurate statements about the treatment of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
questions.passage: GAD treatment has evolved significantly based on cognitive-behavioral research. [In Borkovec's model, worry serves as cognitive avoidance of emotional processing, as the verbal-linguistic nature of worry dampens emotional imagery]. Treatment approaches include [applied relaxation (Ost), which progresses through several stages from progressive muscle relaxation to application in naturally anxiety-provoking situations]. Regarding pharmacotherapy, [buspirone is a 5-HT1A partial agonist for GAD that is non-sedating, has no dependence potential, but has a slow onset of 2-4 weeks]. Some researchers have emphasized that [the key cognitive target in Dugas's model of GAD treatment is catastrophic misinterpretation of bodily sensations]. Additionally, [worry exposure involves deliberately imagining the worst-case scenario without engaging avoidance strategies]. Finally, [flooding to the most catastrophic worry scenario is the first-line behavioral treatment for GAD].

highlightableSegments.text: In Borkovec's model, worry serves as cognitive avoidance of emotional processing, as the verbal-linguistic nature of worry dampens emotional imagery
applied relaxation (Ost), which progresses through several stages from progressive muscle relaxation to application in naturally anxiety-provoking situations
buspirone is a 5-HT1A partial agonist for GAD that is non-sedating, has no dependence potential, but has a slow onset of 2-4 weeks
the key cognitive target in Dugas's model of GAD treatment is catastrophic misinterpretation of bodily sensations
worry exposure involves deliberately imagining the worst-case scenario without engaging avoidance strategies
flooding to the most catastrophic worry scenario is the first-line behavioral treatment for GAD

questions.explanation: Borkovec's model correctly identifies worry as cognitive avoidance of emotional processing. Applied relaxation (Ost) progresses through stages from PMR to rapid relaxation to application training. Buspirone is accurately described as a 5-HT1A partial agonist for GAD. Worry exposure involves deliberately imagining worst-case scenarios. However, the key cognitive target in Dugas's model is intolerance of uncertainty, NOT catastrophic misinterpretation of bodily sensations (which is Clark's model of panic). Flooding is not the first-line behavioral treatment for GAD; CBT and applied relaxation are first-line.

questions.stem: Arrange the 8 phases of the EMDR protocol in their correct sequential order:

items.text: History Taking -- Identify target memories, current triggers, and future desired behaviors
Preparation -- Establish therapeutic relationship; teach self-regulation skills
Assessment -- Activate target memory; identify image, negative cognition, VOC, SUDS
Desensitization -- Bilateral stimulation while focusing on target memory until SUDS = 0
Installation -- Strengthen positive cognition until VOC = 7
Body Scan -- Identify and process residual somatic disturbance
Closure -- Return client to equilibrium using self-regulation strategies
Reevaluation -- Check treatment effects at next session; identify new targets

questions.explanation: The EMDR 8-phase protocol follows a specific sequence: (1) History Taking, (2) Preparation, (3) Assessment (activating the target memory and establishing baseline measures), (4) Desensitization (bilateral stimulation until SUDS = 0), (5) Installation (strengthening positive cognition until VOC = 7), (6) Body Scan (checking for residual somatic disturbance), (7) Closure (returning to equilibrium), and (8) Reevaluation (reviewing at the next session).

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of Ost's Applied Relaxation technique in the correct order from first to last:

items.text: Progressive muscle relaxation (full tension-release cycles for all muscle groups)
Release-only relaxation (releasing tension without initial tensing)
Cue-controlled relaxation (pairing relaxation with a cue word)
Differential relaxation (relaxing in non-demanding everyday situations)
Rapid relaxation (achieving relaxation in 20-30 seconds)
Application training (using the skill in naturally anxiety-provoking situations)

questions.explanation: Ost's Applied Relaxation progresses systematically: (1) Progressive muscle relaxation teaches the basic skill, (2) Release-only relaxation shortens the process by eliminating the tension phase, (3) Cue-controlled relaxation pairs relaxation with a verbal cue for faster induction, (4) Differential relaxation practices the skill in low-demand situations, (5) Rapid relaxation achieves a relaxed state in 20-30 seconds, and (6) Application training uses the skill in real anxiety-provoking situations. This progressive approach is an empirically supported treatment for GAD.

questions.stem: A researcher conducts a study comparing ERP alone versus SSRI medication alone for OCD treatment, measuring Y-BOCS scores at baseline, end of treatment, 6-month follow-up, and 12-month follow-up (after treatment/medication discontinuation).
questions.question: Which interpretation BEST explains the divergence between groups after treatment discontinuation?

options.text: SSRIs produce superior symptom reduction during active treatment, but effects rebound after discontinuation
ERP produces equivalent or superior long-term outcomes because new learning persists after treatment ends, while SSRI benefits typically disappear after discontinuation
Both treatments produce lasting effects, but the SSRI group shows a practice effect on repeated Y-BOCS administration
The divergence reflects regression to the mean in the SSRI group rather than actual treatment differences

questions.explanation: Research shows that ERP alone produces equivalent or superior long-term outcomes compared to medication alone for OCD, with lower relapse rates after treatment discontinuation. The data illustrate that while both treatments reduce symptoms during active treatment, the SSRI group's Y-BOCS scores rise substantially after discontinuation (relapse), while ERP gains are well-maintained. This is because ERP produces new learning (habituation and inhibitory associations) that persists, whereas SSRI benefits depend on continued medication.

questions.stem: A therapist monitors SUDS ratings during a 90-minute flooding session for a client with specific phobia. The following data represent the client's SUDS ratings at 15-minute intervals during the session.
questions.question: If the session had been terminated at the 15-minute mark, what would be the MOST likely clinical consequence?

options.text: The client would experience partial habituation with modest therapeutic benefit
Premature termination while anxiety is still elevated could sensitize the client and increase fear through incubation
The brief exposure would serve as an adequate desensitization trial with slower but equivalent outcomes
The client would develop a tolerance for the feared stimulus that generalizes across contexts

questions.explanation: The data show that SUDS peaked at 15 minutes (90) and then gradually decreased through habituation, reaching 20 by 90 minutes. Premature termination of a flooding session while anxiety is still elevated (or rising) can actually sensitize the client and increase fear -- a process called incubation. This is why flooding sessions must be of sufficient duration to allow anxiety to decrease. Session duration of 60-90 minutes is typically recommended for prolonged exposure exercises.

questions.stem: Categorize each treatment component or technique into the correct therapy approach:

items.text: Imaginal exposure narrated in present tense, recorded for homework
Challenging Beliefs Worksheets targeting stuck points
Cognitive defusion (changing the relationship to thoughts)
Breathing retraining as a coping skill
Identifying assimilated and over-accommodated beliefs
Values clarification and committed action

questions.explanation: PE components include imaginal exposure (narrated in present tense, recorded for homework) and breathing retraining. CPT components include Challenging Beliefs Worksheets and identifying assimilated vs. over-accommodated stuck points across themes of safety, trust, power, esteem, and intimacy. ACT components include cognitive defusion (changing the relationship to thoughts rather than thought content) and values clarification with committed action. Each approach has a distinct theoretical mechanism for addressing trauma and anxiety.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical feature or treatment approach to the anxiety disorder it MOST specifically applies to:

items.text: Interoceptive exposure (hyperventilation, spinning, straw breathing)
Heimberg's Cognitive Behavioral Group Therapy (CBGT)
Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)
Catastrophic misinterpretation of bodily sensations
Reducing self-focused attention and safety behaviors (Clark & Wells model)
Response prevention targeting both behavioral and mental rituals

questions.explanation: Panic disorder is treated with interoceptive exposure and cognitive restructuring of catastrophic misinterpretations of bodily sensations (Clark's model; Barlow & Craske). Social anxiety disorder is treated with Heimberg's CBGT (cognitive restructuring + in-session exposures) and Clark & Wells' model targeting self-focused attention and safety behaviors. OCD is treated with ERP, which includes response prevention targeting both behavioral compulsions and mental rituals.
